Description: Primary operating bank account used for all daily business transactions including customer deposits, revenue collections, vendor payments, payroll processing, electronic fund transfers (EFT), Interac e-Transfers, wire transfers, cheque clearing, debit card purchases, and automatic withdrawals. This is the main account where business income is deposited and operating expenses are paid from. Used for accounts payable bill payments, accounts receivable deposits, online banking transactions, direct deposits to employees, preauthorized debits for recurring expenses like utilities and rent, and general cash management. Bank reconciliations are performed monthly to ensure accuracy between the GL balance and bank statement balance.

Interest-bearing savings account used to hold excess cash reserves, emergency funds, or temporarily park surplus operating funds not immediately needed for day-to-day business operations. Earns interest income on deposited balances while maintaining high liquidity and easy access to funds. Common uses include setting aside money for upcoming tax payments, building working capital reserves, saving for planned capital expenditures, accumulating funds for seasonal cash flow fluctuations, or earning returns on idle cash between major business expenses. Interest earned is taxable income reported on T2 corporate tax return or personal income tax for sole proprietors. May include high-interest savings accounts (HISA), money market accounts, or term deposits with flexible withdrawal terms.

Small amount of physical cash kept on business premises in a locked cash box or safe for minor day-to-day expenses that are impractical to pay by cheque, credit card, or electronic transfer. Typically maintained at a fixed amount (e.g., $100-$500) using an imprest system where the fund is periodically replenished. Common petty cash expenses include emergency office supplies, coffee and snacks for meetings, parking meter coins, postage stamps, taxi fares, courier tips, small equipment repairs under $50, emergency lunch for staff working late, minor cleaning supplies, and spontaneous small purchases. Requires proper documentation with receipts and petty cash vouchers for each disbursement to maintain accountability and support tax deductions. Reconciled regularly by counting cash on hand plus receipts to equal the fixed fund amount. All disbursements must have valid business purposes to be tax-deductible.

Money owed to the business by customers and clients for goods sold or services provided on credit terms. Represents outstanding customer invoices that have been issued but payment has not yet been received. Includes trade receivables from normal business operations with payment terms typically ranging from net 15, net 30, to net 60 days. Also includes unpaid sales invoices, service billings, progress billings for ongoing projects, and any other amounts due from customers. This account increases when sales are made on credit and decreases when customer payments are received and deposited. Proper management requires aging analysis to track overdue invoices, follow-up on late payments, and identify collection issues. Should be reviewed regularly for potentially uncollectible accounts that may need to be written off or provided for in the allowance for doubtful accounts. Important metric for calculating days sales outstanding (DSO) and monitoring cash flow from operations. For GST/HST purposes, tax may be owing even before customer payment is received.

Contra-asset account that estimates the portion of accounts receivable that may not be collectible due to customer defaults, bankruptcies, disputes, or financial difficulties. Reduces the net realizable value of accounts receivable on the balance sheet to reflect a more realistic expected collection amount. Created through bad debt expense entries based on historical collection experience, aging analysis of receivables, assessment of specific customer credit risks, and general economic conditions affecting payment likelihood. Methods include percentage of sales method, percentage of receivables method, or aging schedule analysis. When specific accounts are determined to be uncollectible, they are written off against this allowance rather than directly reducing revenue. This follows the matching principle and conservatism principle in accounting by recognizing potential losses in the period the revenue was earned rather than waiting until actual default occurs. Required under ASPE and IFRS to present accounts receivable at net realizable value. Reviewed and adjusted quarterly or annually.

Goods and products held by the business for sale to customers, including finished goods ready for sale, work-in-progress partially completed, raw materials to be used in production, and supplies consumed in the manufacturing process. For retail businesses, includes all merchandise on shelves and in warehouses available for resale. For manufacturers, includes raw materials, components, work-in-process at various production stages, and finished goods awaiting shipment. For service businesses, may include supplies and parts used to deliver services. Valued using cost methods such as FIFO (first-in-first-out), weighted average cost, or specific identification. Must be valued at lower of cost or net realizable value (LCNRV) per Canadian ASPE Section 3031 or IAS 2 under IFRS. Physical inventory counts performed periodically (usually annually) to verify quantities and identify shrinkage from theft, damage, or obsolescence. Proper inventory management is critical for working capital, cash flow, and determining accurate cost of goods sold. Inventory purchases increase this account while inventory sold (transferred to COGS) decreases it.
Long-term tangible assets like machinery, computers, furniture, vehicles, and tools used in business operations. Subject to depreciation.
Contra-asset account tracking total depreciation expense claimed on equipment and other depreciable assets over their useful life.
Money owed to suppliers and vendors for goods or services purchased on credit. Bills received but not yet paid.
Wages, salaries, and commissions earned by employees but not yet paid. Accrued compensation owing to staff.
Interest expense accrued on loans, mortgages, or credit facilities but not yet paid to lenders.
GST/HST collected from customers on taxable sales that must be remitted to Canada Revenue Agency (CRA).
GST/HST paid on business purchases that can be claimed as input tax credits (ITCs) and offset against sales tax collected.
Employer CPP, EI contributions, and employee source deductions withheld from paycheques owing to CRA.
Corporate income tax or personal income tax (for sole proprietors) owing to federal and provincial tax authorities.
Term loans, mortgages, lines of credit, or other borrowings with repayment terms exceeding one year.
Capital invested by business owner(s). Cash or assets contributed to start or expand the business.
Money withdrawn by owner(s) from the business for personal use. Reduces equity in sole proprietorships and partnerships.
Cumulative net income retained in the business rather than distributed to owners. Profit reinvested for growth.
Revenue from selling products or providing services. Main source of business income from core operations.
Price reductions given to customers for early payment, bulk purchases, or promotional offers. Contra-revenue account.
Interest earned on bank accounts, term deposits, GICs, or loans made to others. Investment income.
Cost of goods purchased for resale. Direct cost of merchandise, raw materials, or inventory bought from suppliers.
Cost of boxes, bags, wrapping materials, labels, and containers used to package products for sale or shipment.
Freight, courier, and delivery charges to ship products to customers. Direct costs of getting goods to buyers.
Value of inventory on hand at the beginning of the accounting period. Starting stock for COGS calculation.
Value of inventory remaining at end of accounting period. Ending stock that reduces COGS in the period.
Costs for developing new products, services, or processes. Innovation and technical research expenses. May qualify for SR&ED tax credits.
Paid promotions including online ads, print ads, radio, TV commercials, billboards, and sponsored content.
Marketing campaigns, promotional materials, trade shows, branding, social media marketing, and customer acquisition costs.
Employee wages, salaries, bonuses, and commissions. Gross pay before deductions for all staff members.
Payments to independent contractors, freelancers, and consultants. Non-employee labour costs.
Additional payroll-related costs such as recruitment fees, temporary agency fees, and payroll processing charges.
Employee benefits including health insurance, dental coverage, life insurance, retirement plan contributions, and wellness programs.
Employer portion of CPP and EI premiums. Required contributions to Canada Pension Plan and Employment Insurance.
Internet service provider fees, web hosting, domain names, cloud services, and online subscriptions.
Software licenses, SaaS subscriptions, accounting software, CRM systems, productivity tools, and application fees.

Monthly or annual lease payments for business premises including office space, retail storefront, commercial warehouse, industrial facilities, manufacturing plants, co-working spaces, storage units, or any other rented real estate property used for business operations. Includes base rent payments under commercial lease agreements, triple net leases (NNN), gross leases, or modified gross leases. May also include lease payments for equipment rentals on operating leases such as photocopiers, vehicles, machinery, or computers if not capitalized. Common for businesses that do not own their operating facilities and instead pay landlords or property management companies for the right to occupy and use commercial space. Rent is typically paid monthly in advance and is a fixed operating expense, though some leases may include percentage rent based on sales revenue or have escalation clauses with annual increases tied to CPI (Consumer Price Index) or fixed percentage increases. Fully tax-deductible as a business expense in the year paid or payable. Lease agreements should specify payment terms, renewal options, maintenance responsibilities, permitted uses, subletting restrictions, and termination clauses. For GST/HST purposes, commercial rent is generally subject to tax and ITCs can be claimed. Personal use portion of home office rent for sole proprietors must be prorated and only business portion is deductible.
Municipal property taxes on owned business real estate. Realty taxes assessed by local government.
Electricity, natural gas, heating, water, sewer services, and waste disposal for business premises.
Vehicle fuel, maintenance, repairs, insurance, registration, and parking for business vehicles. Automobile operating costs.
Business meals, client entertainment, team lunches. Only 50% deductible for income tax purposes per CRA rules.
Business cards, letterhead, brochures, flyers, invoices, and other printed materials for business use.
Canada Post postage, courier services, shipping supplies, and delivery charges for business correspondence and packages.
Landline, mobile phone plans, business cell phones, long-distance charges, and telecommunications services.
Pens, paper, folders, staplers, toner, ink cartridges, and general stationery for office operations.
Accounting, bookkeeping, legal, consulting services. Payments to CPAs, lawyers, business advisors, and professional consultants.
Routine repairs and upkeep of equipment, machinery, vehicles, and facilities. Does not increase asset value.
Janitorial supplies, cleaning products, disinfectants, and janitorial service contracts for business premises.
Customer invoices written off as uncollectible. Accounts receivable that cannot be recovered.
Professional association memberships, chamber of commerce dues, trade organization fees, and industry subscriptions.
Training courses, conferences, seminars, workshops, and continuing education for employees and owners.
Business liability insurance, property insurance, equipment insurance, errors and omissions coverage, and commercial insurance policies.
Temporary holding account for transactions whose proper classification is unknown or pending investigation.
Non-cash expense allocating the cost of capital assets over their useful life. CCA (Capital Cost Allowance) for tax purposes.
Interest charges on business loans, lines of credit, mortgages, credit cards, and other borrowed funds.
Bank service charges, transaction fees, monthly account fees, wire transfer fees, and NSF charges.
Current year corporate income tax expense for federal and provincial taxes on business profits.
